title-group.article-title: Effect of curatives and fillers on vulcanization, mechanical, heat aging, and dynamic properties of silicone rubber and fluororubber blends

article-meta.aff: College of Materials Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, PR China.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Jianhua Guo, College of Materials Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, PR China Email: psjhguo@scut.edu.cn

abstract.p: The cure characteristics and mechanical properties of gum and filled silicone rubber (MVQ), fluororubber (FKM), and MVQ-FKM blends with different compositions were investigated before and after aging. The rheometric study showed that optimum cure properties were obtained using the curing system of dicumyl peroxide (DCP) and triallylisocyanurate (TAIC). From varying the curing agents, the optimum levels of DCP and TAIC were found to be 2.0 phr and 1.5 phr, respectively. The addition of different fillers and their loading influenced the cure behaviors, with increased torque and scorch time compared with that of gum blends. The filled 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends showed overall performance in mechanical properties. Post-curing improved the strength of MVQ-FKM blends, especially the blends with a higher proportion of FKM. Swelling of the blends was reduced with the addition of fillers and the increased incorporation of FKM. Dynamic mechanical analysis showed two tan δ peaks corresponding to MVQ and FKM phase for filled blends, respectively. The storage modulus of the blends increased with the addition of fumed silica, indicating the presence of polymer–filler interaction.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The demand for high temperature and oil resistance elastomers is growing. The end users of such polymers in the automobile, aerospace, offshore, and insulation industries impose stringent product performance standards under elevated temperatures and in hostile chemical environments. Fluororubber of various types is capable of satisfying such demands because of their inherent heat resistance through CF bonding, 1 which is used as a specialty polymer in a variety of applications such as seals, o-rings, tubes, hose, and cables. One disadvantage of this material is its lack of low temperature resistance. At the same time, silicone rubber by comparison with fluororubber is an inexpensive product having an extremely low glass temperature (lower than −100°C), and of which the vulcanizate is distinguished by good hot air aging, high ozone resistance, radiation resistance, and electrical properties. 2 Accordingly, some attempts have been made to combine fluororubber and silicone rubber. Ghosh et al. 3,4 reported on the processing behavior, physical properties and dielectric properties of the blends of silicone rubber andfluororubber based on tetrafluoroethylene/propylene/vinylidene terpolymer. Ghosh 5 also carried out a study on flammability, thermal stability and hot oil resistance of silicone rubber, fluororubber and their blends. Gerhard Langstein et al. 6 studied the combinations of polyorganosiloxanes and fluororubbers containing double bonds by Si–H addition. However, the obvious combination in the formof a simple blend is unsuccessful due to the incompatibility of the two classes of polymers, and as a consequence the compatibility of MVQ and FKM had beeninvestigated in our earlier work. 7 It has also been attempted in this regard to co-vulcanize the two elastomers. However, these two polymers use different types of curing agent and filler in actual applications. Finding a common curative and filler system is needed in order to obtain excellent rubber vulcanizate.

Several articles have recently taken up the vulcanization and physical properties of individual rubbers. Eun-Soo Park 8 studied the reinforcement of silicone rubber imparted by different types of fillers such as glass fiber, wollastonite, and fluororubber. The effect of Al2O3 or ZnO fillers on the thermal conductivity and coefficient of thermal expansion of the silicone rubber were investigated by Sim et al. 9 Wu et al. 10 studied the reinforcement of silicone rubber using quartz, talc, and wollastonite as the fillers prepared by ultra-fine crushing and surface chemical modifying with A-151 and B-5 coupling agent. Likewise, the mechanism of the post curing of fluororubber wasreported by Smith and Perkins. 11 Righetti et al. 12 investigated the effect of MT carbon black loading on the glass transition temperature (T g) of a swollen crosslinked and filled fluororubber. The effect of some fillers such as ISAF, FEF, SRF, and silica on cure, mechanical, aging, and swelling properties of fluororubber and acrylic rubber–fluororubber blends was investigated by Kader et al. 13 However, there have been veryfew reports in the literature on the effect of curative and fillers on the cure characteristics and physical properties of MVQ and FKM blends.

This article is centered on the study of the cure characteristics and strength properties of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends of varying compositions. It also will focus on the aging behavior, swelling, compression set, and dynamic mechanical properties of these blends, as they are expected to perform at high temperatures and in oil environment.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Silicone rubber (MVQ), PS02 [ethenyl content 0.06 mol%, molecular weight 650,000] was obtained from Shenri Silicone Co. Ltd. (Shenzhen, China). Fluororubber (FKM), F2463, a terpolymer of vinylidene fluoride, hexafluoropropylene, and tetrafluoroethylene [66% F, 1.5% H], was provided by Chengdu Daohong Co. Ltd. (Sichuan, China). FKM-g-A174, 7 was prepared in our library. Dicumyl peroxide (DCP), purity 98%, was provided by Fangruida Chemical Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Triallyl isocyanurate (TAIC), active 97%, was provided by Huangyandonghai Chemicals Co. Ltd. (Zhejiang, China). Bisphenol AF and benzyltriphenylphosphonium chloride (BPP) were provided by Dupont Chemical Co., Ltd., USA. N,N′-dicinnamylidene-1,6-hexanediamine (Diak #3) were provided by Chenguang Fluoro & Silicone Polymer Co., Ltd., China. Fumed silica, QS-20A, was supplied by Tokuyama Co. Ltd., Japan. All the other chemicals including reagent-grade products were used without further purification. The molecular structures of MVQ and FKM were shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: The molecular structures of MVQ (a) and FKM (b).

sec.title: Preparation of the Samples
sec.p: MVQ was mixed with FKM in blend ratios of 100:0, 80:20, 50:50, 20:80 and 0:100 (w/w) with and without fillers in a two roll miller (model XK-160, Zhanjiang Rubber and Plastic Machinery Co. Ltd., China) at 60°C. FKM was first introduced in the miller. MVQ was added after 1 min and mixed with FKM for the next 3 min. Within 2 and 4 min for gum and filled compounds, respectively, the compounding ingredients, listed in Tables 1–3, were added in this sequence:
Ca(OH)2→MgO→fillers→curing agents.

The formula symbols of gum and filled MVQ-FKM blends with different blend ratio are G1 to G5, F1 to F5, respectively. The formula symbols of MVQ-FKM blends with different curing systems and different levels of DCP are C1 to C2, D1 to D4, respectively. The formula symbols of the blends filled with different types of fillers and different loadings of fumed silica are S1 to S7, respectively.

The samples were then molded in a two-plate hydraulic press (model XLB-D, Zhejiang Hongtu Co. Ltd., China) at 165°C at a pressure of 13.5 MPa. The molding time was adjusted depending on the optimum cure time determined from a rheometer (model MR-C3, Ruidayuchen Co. Ltd., Beijing, China). The test specimens were cut from molded slabs approximately 1.0 mm thick. The compression set specimens were molded in order to obtain samples that were circular discs 13 mm thick and 30 mm in diameter. The post curing of test specimens of all mixes was carried out in an oven at 250°C for 4 h.

sec.title: Cure Characteristics
sec.p: The cure behaviors were obtained from an oscillating disc rheometer at 165°C for 30 min.

sec.title: Mechanical Tests
sec.p: The tensile strength and tear strength of samples were tested with a Zwick Universal Testing Machine (model Z010, Germany) at 25°C with a crosshead speed of 500 mm min−1 according to ASTM D412-99 and ASTM D624-2000, respectively. The hardness was determined as ASTM D2240-97.

sec.title: Aging Studies
sec.p: The heat aging tests were carried out in an oven at 200°C for 48 h. The tensile properties after heat aging were measured according to ASTM D412-99 and the hardness (shore A) after aging was tested according to ASTM D2240-97.

sec.title: Compression Set
sec.p: The compression set test was done under a constant compressive strain of 25% according to ASTM D 395-98 at 200°C for 48 h.

sec.title: Swelling
sec.p:
Circular test pieces with a radius of 20 mm were die-cut from a molded sheet that was 1.0–1.5 mm thick. An oil swelling study was also carried out in ASTM #1 and #3 oil at 200°C for 48 h according to the ASTM D471-93, respectively, and the swollen samples were weighed accurately and quickly in a glass-stoppered bottle after blotting with a filter paper. Volume swelling in percentage was calculated using the following equation. (1) q−1=W2W1−1ρc/ρs
where q is the ratio of swollen volume to original volume; (q−1) is the percentage of volume swell/100; W 1 and W 2 are the weights of the specimen before and after swelling, respectively; and ρc and ρs are the densities of the specimen and the test solvent, respectively.

sec.title: Dynamic Mechanical Analysis
sec.p: Dynamic mechanical thermal properties were evaluated on a dynamic mechanical analyzer (DMA 242C, Netzsch Co. Ltd., Germany), under tension mode. The experiments were carried out at a frequency of 5 Hz. Measurements were taken from −100°C to 100°C at a heating rate of 5°C min−1. The storage modulus (E′) and loss tangent (tan δ) were measured for all samples under identical conditions.

sec.title: Choice of Cure System
sec.p: According to a survey of the literature, fluororubber (FKM) containing vinylidene fluoride as a cure site group were crosslinked mainly by blocked diamines and dihydroxy alcohol with an accelerator containing phosphonium ions, 1 and FKM may also be cured by peroxide. 14,15 On the other hand, silicone rubber (MVQ)-containing ethenyl reactive group was cured mostly by a peroxide system.

In the present study, because both MVQ and FKM are involved, several curing agents were tried with a representative 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blend, and the results of such systems are represented in the rheograph curves in Figure 2(a). Acombination of a diamine cure system (Diak #3) with dicumyl peroxide (DCP) (symbol C1) did not raise the torque to an appreciable level in Figure 2(a). Bisphenol AF and DCP (symbol C2) curing increased the torque only after a long period of time and was not adequate for complete crosslinking of the blends. A cure system consisting of DCP and TAIC (symbol F3) showed a better cure graph than two compound curing systems, which may be ascribed to inhibited vulcanization process due to the disturbance between free radical reaction in peroxide system and ionized reaction in diamine and bisphenol AF cure systems. 16,17 Therefore, the balance of the current study on mechanical and dynamic mechanical analysis was carried out on samples cured by DCP and TAIC. The rheograph curves of the blends of varying compositions were shown in Figure 2b. Among all the cure curves, MVQ (symbol F1) showed lower M L and M H and had a higher optimum cure time (Table 1). M L and M H values of theblends gradually increased with an increasing proportion of FKM. Finally, the observed maximum torque for pure FKM (symbol F5) also showed the lowest optimum cure time. It also can be seen from Figure 2(b) that the difference in M H values between pure FKM and the blends with varying compositions was very large, indicating the effect of MVQ on reducing the compound viscosity.

caption.p: Effect of (a) different cure systems; (b) blend ratios; (c) variation in level of DCP; (d) variation in level of fumed silica on rheographs of MVQ-FKM blends.
Formulations and cure characteristics of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends with different blend ratio

fn.p: aParts per hundred of rubber by weight.

sec.p: Figure 2(c) shows the rheograph of the 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blend containing different levels of DCP varied from 0.5 to 2.5 phr (symbol D1 to D4). It can be seenthat the increase in DCP level increased the M L and M H and decreased scorch time and optimum cure time (Table 2). The mechanical properties of the gum blends of 50/50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM cured with different levels of DCP also suggest that maximum properties were reached at 2.0 phr (Table 2). Therefore, all succeeding experiments were carried out at a 2.0 phr level of DCP and a 1.5 phr level of TAIC. This DCP/TAIC curative system helped in getting the optimum properties of the blends.

The effect of different levels of fumed silica in 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM on cure characteristics is represented in Figure 2(d). An increase in filler level increased the M L and M H values (Table 3, symbol S2 to S5). This implies that increasing the level of fumed silica will increase the minimum viscosity of the compound through filler–polymer interaction. The presence of a larger amount of fumed silica increased theT 90 due to the acidity of fumed silica. Among different fillers, fumed silica (symbol F3) imparted a higher M H and diatomite (symbol S6) showed a lower torque, signaling differences in the reinforcing characteristics of different fillers.

caption.p: Formulations, cure characteristics, and mechanical properties of 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends cured with different curing systems and different levels of DCP
Formulations and cure characteristics of 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends filled with different types of fillers and different loadings of fumed silica

sec.title: Stress-Strain Characteristics
sec.p: Response to stress-strain behavior by an elastomer predicts most of its mechanical performance. Such behaviors are dependent on many factors such as temperature, strain rate, and mode of application. The stress-strain curves of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends are represented in Figure 3(a–d). All the curves show the true elastic behavior of the rubbers. Gum MVQ (symbol G1) showed a very low stress level and modulus even at relatively higher deformation (Figure 3a). The low level of stress can be attributed to the low energy requirement for stretching crosslinked elastomer networks. On the other hand, gum FKM (symbol G5) shows a higher level of stress on deformation. The values of the blends with varying compositions fell between those MVQ and FKM. The 80:20 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends showed a lower level of strain at break compared to that of the other blends.

caption.p: Stress-strain curves of MVQ, FKM, and their blends with different compositions: (a) variation of blend ratio (gum blends); (b) variation of blend ratio (40 phr fumed silica filled blends); (c) 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends containing different types of fillers; (d) effect of fumed silica loading on 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blend.

sec.p: The effect of fumed silica on stress-strain behavior of MVQ-FKM blends isdepicted in Figure 3(b). With the addition of fumed silica, silicone rubber showed tremendous improvement in modulus, which indicates that fumed silica has a reinforcing effect on elastic behavior of silicone rubber by forming a rubber–filler network. FKM showed a similar trend and the extent of increase was higher than that of MVQ. The stress-stain curves of MVQ-FKM blends with varying compositions fall between those of MVQ and FKM.

A comparison of stress-deformation curves of 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends to which various types of filler had been added indicates that the filler with small particle sizes and high surface activity required a higher stress level for a given strain (Figure 3c). The following order of stress at break was observed from the stress-strain curves:
Fumed silica > Precipitated silica > CaSiO3 > Diatomite

The stress-strain curves of 50:50 MVQ-FKM blends filled with different levels of fumed silica is represented in Figure 3(d). By increasing the level of fumed silica, the strain level was reduced at a given stress because of limited extensibility. The higher the filler loading, the higher the filler–polymer and filler–filler networks will be and the lower the deformation capacity. The reduction in the strain level was a result of interparticle aggregation of the filler, which resisted the chain extensibility of the polymer chains. Highly filled blends require more stress to attain the same level of deformation of the gum system.

sec.title: Mechanical Properties
sec.p: The performance of any product is easily judged by its strength properties. Tensile failure is regarded as catastrophic tearing by the growth of crack-initiated flaws. Tensile properties can be improved by dissipating most input energy in the form ofheat through an irreversible molecular process. The mechanical properties of thegum and fumed silica filled MVQ and FKM and their blends were shown inTable 4. The tensile strength and 100% modulus of the gum blends increased due to the incorporation of FKM into the blend. The gum fluororubber showed maximum strength (3.1 MPa) and the gum silicone rubber exhibited maximum elongation at break (225%).

caption.p: Physical properties of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends before and after post curing and aging

tr.td: Physical properties after post curing at 250°C for 4 h

fn.p: aValues within parentheses indicate % change of properties after aging at 200°C for 48 h

sec.p: The reinforcing effect of fumed silica was shown in the individual rubbers andtheir blends with uniform increase in tensile strength and reduction in elongation atbreak. MVQ shows drastic improvement in modulus at 100% elongation and tensile strength, from 0.1 MPa and 0.2 MPa, respectively, for the gum compound, to 1.5 MPa and 8.8 MPa, respectively, for the 40 phr fumed silica-filled MVQ. The tear strength also increased, from 3.0 kN m−1 for gum MVQ to 13.5 kN m−1 for the filled compound. The 50:50 blends showed better overall mechanical properties for both the gum and filled compounds. The increase in tensile strength and reduction in elongation of a filled system can be explained by the saltation mechanism 18 (detachment and reattachment of polymer chains with filler particles) and energy dissipation through a breakdown of agglomeration, high viscous flow from filler–polymer chain entanglement, and slippage of rubber molecules along the filler surface. 19,20

The reinforcing effects of different loadings of fumed silica and various fillers ontensile and tear properties of MVQ-FKM blends are shown in Table 5. Amongdifferent fillers fumed silica showed the highest tensile strength, followed by precipitated silica, with the lowest strength observed for the diatomite-filled blend. The effectiveness of reinforcing filler depends on filler characteristics such as size and shape of the particles and, more significantly, on the strength of polymer–filler interactions. 21–23 These interactions increase the effective degree of crosslinking and such an effect is particularly strong if the particles have some reactive surface groups. The small particle size and large surface area of fumed silica provides a greater possibility of polymer–filler interaction and consequent molecular slippage. These processes enhance the tensile strength.

caption.p: Physical properties of filled 50 : 50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends before and after post curing and aging

tr.td: Physical properties after post curing at 250°C for 4 h

fn.p: aValues within parentheses indicate % change of properties after aging at 200°C for 48 h

sec.p: Table 5 depicts the effect of fumed silica loading on the tensile properties of 50:50 MVQ-FKM blends. An increase in filler loading increased the tensile strength from 1.9 MPa for the gum compound to 8.4 MPa for the 40 phr loaded compound. However, the 50 phr loaded blends showed a lower tensile strength of7.9 MPa, which indicates that the reinforcing effect increases with the addition of fumed silica to some extent.

sec.title: Effect of Post Curing
sec.p: The mechanical properties of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends after post curing were shown in Tables 4 and Figure 4. The results show that post curing increases the tensile strength of MVQ, FKM as well as the blends to different magnitudes. The gum and filled blends containing a higher proportion of FKM showed more changes in tensile strength compared to the other blends. It can also be seen that the effect of post curing shows an increase in modulus, tear strength, and hardness for MVQ, FKM, and their blends. However, there was a decrease in elongation at break for all the neat polymers and their blends. The effect of filler types and loading on the mechanical properties of 50:50 MVQ-FKM blends are shown in Table 5. There was also some increase in strength properties and hardness and decrease in elongation in MVQ-FKM blends loaded with different fillers.

During press curing, reaction products such as water generated from the following reaction inhibited the vulcanization process and decreased the strength properties of the blends.
(2)
MgO+2HF→MgF2+H2O

caption.p: Comparison of tensile strength of press cured, post cured, and aged MVQ-FKM blends containing 40 phr fumed silica.

sec.p: The evolved water is easily removed in hot-air atmosphere during post curing. Post curing of MVQ and FKM completed the process of vulcanization to the maximum level which resulting in the increase of strength properties of MVQ-FKM blends.

sec.title: Effect of Aging
sec.p: Aging of polymers normally reduces its useful properties. However, saturated polymers are affected to a lesser extent than olefinic rubbers that contain a double bond, which acts as a reactive site for aging. Tables 4 and 5 show the aging results for MVQ, FKM, and their blends. It can be seen that the modulus and hardness of MVQ, FKM, and their blends increase, however, the tensile strength, tear strength, and elongation decrease after aging. The comparison of tensile strength of aged MVQ-FKM blends containing 40 phr fumed silica is shown in Figure 4. The results show that the tensile strength of MVQ and the blends containing higher proportion of MVQ were affected to a greater extent after aging, which is ascribed to the better thermal resistance properties of FKM than that of MVQ.

sec.title: Compression Set
sec.p: The results of the compression set experiments are shown in Tables 4 and 5. They show that FKM was undergoing the maximum set under both conditions. On the other hand, MVQ showed the minimum set. The blends showed values in between those of MVQ and FKM depending on the proportion of MVQ.

sec.title: Swelling Studies
sec.p: The swelling data of MVQ, FKM, and their blends in ASTM #1 and #3 oil are presented in Figure 5. Gum silicone rubber had the highest swelling data of 33% and 45% in ASTM #1 and #3 oil, respectively. On the other hand, gum FKM showed a lower swelling of 5% and 8% in ASTM #1 and #3 oil, respectively. Increasing the FKM level in the blends gradually reduced the swelling. No blends showed a lower swelling value than FKM.

The reinforcing effect of filler on solvent swelling is clearly seen from the reduction of percent swelling of fumed silica filled MVQ, FKM, and 50:50 (w/w) blends. Fillers interact with rubbers and form a considerable amount of bound rubber through a filler–polymer network, which resists the penetration of solvent molecules into the network, thereby reducing the swelling. The oil resistance of both fumed silica loaded MVQ and FKM and their blends were shown in Figure 5 from the level of swelling of these rubbers in ASTM #1 and #3 oil. Filled FKM vulcanizates showed 3% swell, whereas filled MVQ had about 26% swell. The fumed silica loaded 50:50 MVQ-FKM blends showed less than 10% swell in ASTM #1 oil. The oil resistance of both MVQ and FKM and their blends in ASTM #1 oil is better than that in ASTM #3 oil with higher swell values.

caption.p: Swelling data of gum and filled MVQ, FKM, and their blends.

sec.title: Dynamic Mechanical Analysis
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the temperature dependence of storage modulus (E′) and loss tangent (tan δ) of cured 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends with different composition over the temperature range of −100°C to 100°C. The loss tangent peaks are corresponding to glass-transition temperature (T g). MVQ and FKM showed glass-transition temperature at −43.1°C and 6.5°C, respectively. The 50:50 blends loaded with 40 phr fumed silica showed two Tg at -41.9°C and 5.1°Ccorresponding to T g of MVQ and FKM matrix, respectively. FKM showed higher storage modulus (E′) than that of MVQ. Temperature dependence of E′ and tan δ of filled 50:50 MVQ-FKM blends with different fumed silica loading from10 phr to 40 phr was shown in Figure 7. It exhibited that tan δ values of MVQ-FKM blends filled with different level of fumed silica increased, however, the T g of the blends was seldom changed with the addition of the filler. The effect of the addition of fumed silica was also seen with increasing storage modulus values at all measured temperatures because of the restricted mobility of the polymer chain through crosslinking and polymer–filler networking.

caption.p: Temperature dependence of tan δ (a) and E′ (b) of fumed silica filled 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends with different composition at 5 Hz frequency.
Temperature dependence of tan δ (a) and E′ (b) of filled 50:50 (w/w) MVQ-FKM blends with different fumed silica loading from 10 phr to 40 phr at 5 Hz frequency.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Among various cure systems, a combination of DCP and TAIC yielded good cure characteristics with faster curing speed and higher curing torque. The optimum cure of MVQ-FKM blends is reached with the addition of 2 phr of DCP and 1.5 phr of TAIC. The scorch time and the optimum curing time of MVQ-FKM blends decreased with the increasing addition of DCP. The effect of different levels of fumed silica in 50:50 blends on cure characteristics indicated that an increase in filler level raised the maximum torque. Smaller-particle-size fillers such as fumed silica showed a higher stress level for a given strain. By increasing the level of fumed silica, the strain level was reduced at a given stress. MVQ and FKM blends drastically improved the strength properties with the addition of fumed silica as compared to gum vulcanizates. Post curing increases all the other mechanical properties except elongation at break of MVQ, FKM, and their blends. Further increase in strength properties was shown in the blends containing a higher proportion of FKM. The thermal resistance of MVQ and blends containing a higher proportion of MVQ was affected to a greater extent after aging due to the poor thermo oxidative stability of MVQ compared to FKM. A lower swelling was achieved by adding reinforcing filler for the MVQ-FKM blends. The oil resistance of the blends increased with the increased proportion of FKM in the blends. The storage modulus of MVQ-FKM blends increased but T g of the blends was seldom changed with the addition of fumed silica.
